I agree that the paper contains interesting ideas.

I can also imagine that HashNet is very difficult to implement in existing frameworks (e.g., torch, theano, tensorflow); even if successfully implemented, it will either (1) be *very* slow or (2) cache the indexes, thus saving actually *no* space. So I am not concerned with efficiency improvement.

The authors instead show sub-vector sharing improves, or at least does not hurt, performance compared with other compression method (including LightRNN) and non-compression methods. column39: What I concern of is explicit relation disambiguation. In many cases, there is more than one type of connectives occurred, triggering different types of relations. For example, in the sentence “since Arg1, meanwhile Arg2”, the connective “since” may trigger a causal relation or temporal, and “meanwhile” triggers temporal relation. Could you let me know what relation is held between the arguments when you remove one or both the connectives? Did the selective attention memory model definitely percepts the genuine relation between them? What attention will be focused on by the model for the possible temporal relation and what for causal? I suggest that the insignificant performance achieved by that complex model is probably caused by less consideration taken into the solution of the underlying problems, such as kinds of explicit relation disambiguation. After all, the additional resources (instances of explicit relations) are added to the training data or used to provide pseudo ground-truth data for learning. It is natural for a recognizer to figure out the correspondence between connectives and relations in practice, especially when it will do so for large-scale data, e.g., the instances in Gigaword.

3.5 = I learned some nuggets of knowledge from this paper and would like to see it accepted.

Possibly it'll be helpful/useful to see the messages on the reviewers' message board for this paper. 
Below would be my annonymized post to the fellow reviewers on the message board:

Dear R1 and R2,

R1 is right about hyperparameter sweep being non-independent of each other. I've mentioned it in my review too. Also, manual evaluation on a sample of the test set or significant values would be really good addition to the paper. I believe the significant values can be easily appended to the paper.

There are still many variables to consider but all that cannot be put together in a conference paper, it would have to be an journal publication or a very detailed documentation manual.

Actually, if the author toned down their claims and call it an "hyperparameter ablation study" instead of "massive exploration" and from "novel work" to "meticulous work", I think it's a paper that's great to have in the MT community.

Nevertheless, I think we need more of these work that share a standard benchmark script and look into the effects of the individual hyperparameters. The "attention" experiments are somewhat novel, although there are unpublished work that has similar line of thoughts.

Previously, from the Moses PB- / Syntax-based MT, there're also many blackbox effects. And given the NMT paradigm, it's a fresh start and I think it'll be good to set a good example for future papers to look at the hyperparameters ablation more seriously.

Regards,
R3

The authors do not mention the possible use in reranking of AMR graphs.  Instead, the results are presented in a way that may mislead the reader to think that now there is a linear-time semantic parser. 

Extension to actual semantic parsing of strings should at least be mentioned.

There is no clear connection to (non)context-free string languages or sets of (non)projective dependency graphs used in semantic parsing.  What is written on lines 757-758 is just misleading.

-
Lines 082-099 suggest that the motivation is machine translation, i.e. probabilistic relation between strings and graphs and back.  I did not get any sign that the author can relate this work to (1) probabilistic parsing from strings into AMR graphs or (2) reranking top AMR-parses produced by some parser that can do this.  As a result, the motivation of the work is unclear to me.  It is extremely uninteresting to say that regular languages are obtained if the grammar is as simple as in Fig 5: Instead, we need yields of graphs, and string languages from which to map, probabilistically, to graphs.   But the probability model is not discussed with an appropriate detail.  

I expected to talk about some noncrossing trees over strings when the yield is restricted to strings like CFGs can be intersected with an FSA.  Instead, the authors say that "RGGs are similar to right-linear or left-linear grammars".  Either the author did not understand what is my problem or the formalism is not giving anything new beyond right/left linear grammars.    

After the reply, I am no more so sure if the final paper will be so motivated and clear as I first hoped.  This affects the score.

There are a number of technical points for which I'd like to see some clarifications.

- I am slightly worried that orthogonality is too radical or drastic a solution to the repeated words problem. Have the authors investigated some kind of trade-off in which orthogonality is a soft constraint whose weighting should be learned in order to balance diversity and the original training criterion?

- The proposed method achieves much higher ROUGE scores compared to the baselines. It would be nice to better understand what the model is doing. One possibility which might be problematic is that the diversity attention mechanism allows the model to ignore grammaticality concerns and skip function words, in order to cram more content words and phrases which improve ROUGE scores. 

- On a related evaluation note, it would be nice to see another baseline system which is like the D2 model, but without the constraint of equation (12). This would let us understand the impact of adding another LSTM layer for the context vectors on performance, as opposed to the orthogonality constraint.

Verb Physics: Relative Physical Knowledge of Actions and Objects
column39:
About clarity / accessibility: 1) Currently, the paper and especially Section 4 (the model) cannot be followed by an audience that doesn't have a specific background on factor graphs. This is a major flaw. I would like the authors to explain how they plan to make the paper accessible to a bigger part of the ACL community -- but frankly I'm not sure this can be accepted without a 2nd reviewing round, since it implies a major rewrite. 2) In the introduction, authors only say "we frame knowledge acquisition as joint inference over two closely related puzzles: inferring relative physical knowledge about object pairs while simultaneously reasoning about physical implications of actions". There are many different ways one could do this. The introduction (or some other section early on) should summarize the approach, without technicalities. I would appreciate it if authors provided this summary in their response.

Regarding the second experiment: I would like authors to explain why they didn't apply model B in the second experiment, and what they can say about their model not improving over the baseline in this experiment (I'm referring to test set results, of course). I would also like them to give more details about the baseline and explain why it is an adequate baseline.
